title: DSAN Handbook
text:
1 Welcome to Georgetown!
It is with great pleasure that we welcome you to the Georgetown University Data Science and Analytics Program! As a new student, you are about to embark on an exciting journey that will shape your future in many ways. We want to assure you that our institution is committed to providing you with the best possible learning experience. From the moment you set foot on campus, you will be immersed in a dynamic and diverse community that values academic excellence, innovation, and inclusivity. We understand that starting at a new university can be both thrilling and daunting, but we want you to know that we are here to support you every step of the way. Our faculty, staff, and student leaders are dedicated to helping you succeed academically, personally, and professionally. We encourage you to take advantage of the many resources and opportunities available to you, both inside and outside the classroom. As a Georgetown student, you will have access to cutting-edge facilities and technologies, as well as a wide range of extracurricular activities and community service programs. We hope that you will take advantage of all that our program (and the campus) has to offer, and that you will make lasting connections with your peers, mentors, and alumni. This will be a fun, exciting, challenging, rewarding, and amazing experience – enjoy every minute of it! We look forward to seeing you thrive, grow, and make your mark in the world! This is a long email so take your time and please read it fully and very carefully – then save it. This email contains A LOT of critical information about the Fall term, required events, Fall registration and class options, important links, MyAccess, GoCards, orientation, housing, transportation, Q&A, and more.
Welcome to the Data Science and Analytics (DSAN) Departmental Handbook! This site serves as a centralized hub for finding information on the different courses offered by the department—prerequisites, topics covered, etc.—to help you navigate during your journey through the program.
You can browse course offerings in the table below, and use the search bar above the table along with the category selector on the right to narrow down the courses displayed. Click on the heading of a column to sort the table by that column.



If you have any questions or concerns about the content in the handbook, feel free to contact us.

title: 2  Required Summer R and Python Bootcamp
text:
2.1 Bootcamp Info Session
Zoom Recording: https://georgetown.zoom.us/rec/share/rwMbDJK9R_QKYzl0QpmBt0tLu_YwvedbkV3X1jb1BS9ONHETUXESIAUgUe5vQyP6.seCGqELI8f5HwDPZ
crumbs: 2  Required Summer R and Python Bootcamp

title: 2  Required Summer R and Python Bootcamp
text:
2.2 About the Bootcamp
The bootcamp is not structured as a traditional “class,” but rather as a self-directed learning experience. It is completely asynchronous, allowing you to work at your own pace and convenience. The content provided will guide you through various exercises and challenges in R and Python, enabling you to become proficient in both programming languages. Throughout the bootcamp, a team of Teaching Assistants (TAs) will be there to support and guide you every step of the way. We understand that learning advanced programming in R and Python can sometimes be challenging, but you don’t have to do it alone. Your assigned TA will be your direct point of contact and will reach out to you via email. They are available to answer any questions you may have, provide assistance with coding, and offer guidance whenever needed. Additionally, the TAs will hold regular office hours and check in with you to ensure you’re making progress and to address any concerns you may have. We encourage you to take full advantage of the expertise and support offered by our TAs as they are here to ensure your success in the bootcamp. We want to emphasize that your learning and understanding of the materials are of utmost importance to us. In this bootcamp, we have adopted a unique approach where a team of TAs will facilitate your learning journey. Please note that this is not a traditional course with a professor, but rather a self-directed learning experience supported by our dedicated TAs. The bootcamp follows a pass/fail grading system, and we want to assure you that while the expectation is to pass each assignment, if you encounter difficulties and do not pass initially, you will have the opportunity to revise and resubmit your work until you achieve a passing grade. Our primary focus is on your growth and mastery of the concepts, so please feel free to seek help from your TAs whenever you don’t fully understand or require additional support. Remember to submit only code that runs successfully, as we value the practical application of your skills. The bootcamp has been carefully developed by three full-time professors: myself, Prof. James Hickman, and Prof. Nakul Padalkar. Additionally, you will have access to extra instructional videos created by our outstanding student TAs. If you feel more comfortable with one language over the other, please adapt your focus accordingly. For example, if you excel in R but are a beginner in Python, prioritize completing the R assignments quickly and allocate more time to mastering Python. The same principle applies in reverse. It’s crucial to assess your own learning needs and dedicate the necessary time to become proficient in both languages. While this bootcamp serves as a review, you are encouraged to explore additional resources and tutorials if needed. The goal of this bootcamp is to ensure that you achieve a good or expert level in both R and Python. When the Fall term begins, it is expected that all students possess a strong command of these programming languages, as they will be utilized in DSAN 5000 and ANLY 5100. BOOTCAMP LINK
(Please note that we will be updating this soon, right now the gu domain is not working. But we will update everything before June 6th, especially the Instructions and Lead TA pages) https://jfh.georgetown.domains/bootcamp Username = GU_student_1 Password = GU_student_1 Zoom Recording: https://georgetown.zoom.us/rec/share/rwMbDJK9R_QKYzl0QpmBt0tLu_YwvedbkV3X1jb1BS9ONHETUXESIAUgUe5vQyP6.seCGqELI8f5HwDPZ DATES The bootcamp officially begins on June 6th 2023, and you can refer to the Boot Camp Schedule Page for specific dates and deadlines. Each week, except for the Extra material, you will have a short assignment to complete. The bootcamp will conclude on August 15th 2023, but the assignment submission deadline is August 1st, 11:59 p.m. Eastern Time (ET). Should you have any questions throughout the bootcamp, please feel free to reach out to your TA. They will be available until August 15th, 11:59 p.m. ET to assist you. DSAN5000 BOOTCAMP QUIZ Once the bootcamp concludes, we highly encourage you to maintain your coding momentum and continue practicing with R and Python. The journey of learning data science and analytics is an ongoing process, and consistent practice will help solidify your skills and deepen your understanding. We want you to be well-prepared for the challenges and rigor of our program, so it’s important to note that in the first week of the fall semester, we will have an opening quiz in DSAN5000 that will assess your proficiency in the bootcamp material. These skills are crucial for your success in our program, and we believe that building a strong foundation through the bootcamp will greatly benefit you as you progress further. Keep coding, keep learning, and embrace the continuous growth and development that comes with mastering R and Python. TA INFORMATION Should you have any questions throughout the bootcamp, please feel free to reach out to your TA. They will be available until August 15th, 11:59 p.m. ET to assist you. Throughout the bootcamp, a team of dedicated DSAN Teaching Assistants (TAs) will be available to assist you. They will not only evaluate your work but also provide insights and answer questions from a student’s perspective. Your assigned TA may also host online discussion sessions, and they will notify you directly of the time and date. Anthony Moubarak am4315@georgetown.edu Lead TA Corrina Calanoc clc317@georgetown.edu Lead TA Katie Mead kam515@georgetown.edu Bootcamp Manager
I have personally chosen these TAs from many TA applications because of their exceptional skills, talents, and proficiency in both R and Python. Equally important, I also chose them for their kindness, friendliness, and eagerness to help their fellow students. Rest assured, our TAs are not only highly knowledgeable but also dedicated to creating a supportive and inclusive learning environment. They are here to assist you in your academic journey and provide guidance whenever you need it. Feel free to reach out to them for any assistance or clarification you may require—they are here to ensure your success and help you thrive. Again, our primary focus is on your growth and mastery of the concepts, so please feel free to seek help from your TAs whenever you don’t fully understand or require additional support. Remember to submit only code that runs successfully, as we value the practical application of your skills. HOW TO SUBMIT AN ASSIGNMENT To submit your assignments, please email them to your assigned TA. Please ensure that you submit your deliverables in a ZIP folder with the following format: YOUR_NAME_Assignment_xx (e.g., PURNA_GAMAGE_Assignment_6). You can access the bootcamp materials through this link: https://jfh.georgetown.domains/bootcamp Username = GU_student_1 Password = GU_student_1 Inside each week’s folder, you will find a README.doc file that provides specific instructions for that assignment. Remember to package your submission in a ZIP folder. Grades are PASS or REDO Grades in the bootcamp are either PASS or REDO. We want to assure you that if you don’t initially succeed in an assignment, you will have the opportunity to redo it and improve your understanding. However, it’s important to emphasize that completion of the entire bootcamp and timely submission of assignments are essential for your success in the program. The bootcamp is designed to equip you with the necessary knowledge and skills in Python and R, which are vital for daily labs and final capstone projects in every class. The program is rigorous, and a solid grasp of these programming languages is integral to your academic journey. Therefore, we strongly encourage you to actively participate in the bootcamp and submit all assignments to maximize your chances of success in the program. We encourage you to enjoy the process and fully engage with R and Python until you feel comfortable and confident in your knowledge and abilities. For R, we recommend using RStudio, and for Python, we suggest using Python3, Anaconda, and VS-Code. However, if you prefer alternative Integrated Development Environments (IDEs), feel free to use them. FAQS What if I need to be late on a submission? Answer: While it is not advised, we understand that unforeseen circumstances may arise. However, please make every effort to complete the bootcamp assignments by August 1st to stay on track. Where can I find the name of the TA assigned to me? Answer: Your TA will contact you via email. Can I finish the bootcamp early? Answer: Absolutely! If you feel confident in your R and Python skills before the official end date, you may proceed. The important thing is to ensure that you have a strong foundation in both programming languages. I am exceptionally proficient in R. Can I skip those assignments and focus solely on Python? Answer: No, we encourage you to complete all the assignments. Your expertise in R will allow you to complete the related assignments more quickly, enabling you to dedicate more time to mastering Python. Can I contact the lead TAs if I have any questions? Answer: Yes of course! While your first contact should be your own designated TA, you can still contact the lead TAs for any further assistance. We hope you have a wonderful time engaging with R and Python during this bootcamp. Remember that coding can be both challenging and rewarding. If you have any uncertainties or need assistance throughout the bootcamp, your TAs are here to help. We are dedicated to ensuring your success and learning experience. However, as I have mentioned earlier, while your first contact should be your own designated TA and then the lead TA, if there are some unresovable issues, you are always welcome to email me anytime. Once again, welcome to Georgetown University and best of luck with the bootcamp!
ORIENTATION, EVENTS, AND WORKSHOPS (MANDATORY)
We will host several welcome events. All events are required for all new students. Data Science and Analytics Welcome Orientation Friday, August 21, 10.30 am - 1.30pm Brunch starts at 10:30am on the Mid Campus Terrace. The orientation program starts at 12:30pm in Lohrfink Auditorium. Learn about the program, get to know our faculty and staff, meet new and returning students, and have fun! Zoom Workshop 1: Graduate Learning, Methods, & Expectations hosted by Dr. Kelly Grady (Associate Director, Interdisciplinary Programs, Georgetown Graduate School of Arts & Sciences) Tuesday, August 22, 1-2pm ET https://georgetown.zoom.us/j/95408390743 Workshop 2: Internships, TA, Second-Year Scholarships, and More hosted by Dir. Purna Gamage & Dir. Heather Connor Tuesday, August 22, 3-4pm https://georgetown.zoom.us/j/94409854741 ACTIVATE YOUR GEORGETOWN EMAIL ASAP
If you have not already – get a Georgetown email ASAP and check it every day. Until June 1, we will use both your personal and your GU email.** After June 1, we will only use your GU email. You can find your University NetID and temporary password in your admission letter. Please click on the link provided in the letter to change your password. Georgetown uses Google Apps for email, so once you have changed your password, please review these instructions for signing in to your Georgetown email. Check your Georgetown email every day. This is critical for effective communication.

title: 8  Applying to Graduate: Process & Deadlines
text:
8.1 Graduating in December:
You must apply to graduate via MyAccess by no later than December 1. Please review the information and instructions here: https://grad.georgetown.edu/academics/how-to-graduate/
When you apply to graduate, you will receive occasional updates from Graduate Student Services regarding degree posting, diplomas, etc.
There is only one commencement ceremony each year, and that is in May (usually the third Friday of May). You are more than welcome to return to Georgetown in May to participate in the ceremony!
crumbs: 8  Applying to Graduate: Process & Deadlines

title: 8  Applying to Graduate: Process & Deadlines
text:
8.2 Graduating in May:
You MUST apply to graduate NO LATER THAN FEBRUARY 1 if you wish to have your name and graduation information printed in the Commencement Book.
If you miss the February 1 deadline, you may still apply to graduate until May 1. However, your name and graduation information will not appear in the Commencement Book.
Directions on how to apply to graduate can be found here: http://grad.georgetown.edu/academics/how-to-graduate/. Please select May 31 as your graduation date.
When you apply to graduate, you will receive occasional updates from Graduate Student Services regarding the ceremony, degree posting, diplomas, etc.
crumbs: 8  Applying to Graduate: Process & Deadlines

title: 8  Applying to Graduate: Process & Deadlines
text:
8.3 Graduating in August:
You must apply to graduate via MyAccess by no later than August 1. Please review the information and instructions here: https://grad.georgetown.edu/academics/how-to-graduate/
When you apply to graduate, you will receive occasional updates from Graduate Student Services regarding degree posting, diplomas, etc.
crumbs: 8  Applying to Graduate: Process & Deadlines

title: 9  International Students
text:
9.1 ANLY905 and CPT
If you are an international student(and not graduating in May 2022), you MUST be approved for CPT (Curricular Practical Training) in order to do an internship, and you MUST register for ANLY 905.
Please review the CPT information on the Office of Global Services website: https://internationalservices.georgetown.edu/students/employment/cpt
Please also review the entire CPT and internship process on our program website. Go to the International Student Resources page and scroll down to the link “Internship Information for International Students.” When you read it you will see that our program requires you to submit a Google Form as part of the CPT process. Please thoroughly review the Google Form and follow the instructions for uploading your CPT form to Google Drive (be sure to email Dir.Heather Connor once you have done so).
More Info about CPT:
You can view the CPT module video (Links to an external site.) and video transcript (Links to an external site.) in Box. The module also links to the following resources mentioned in the video: CPT eligible course list (Links to an external site.) CPT application instructions (Links to an external site.) Career Resources for International Students (Links to an external site.) Research a company for a job interview (Links to an external site.) Wilberforce Pamphlet
Requirements 1. You need to read the attached pdf carefully. 2. Complete & Submit the DSAN CPT Request Form. This is the DSAN CPT Request Form, which is the first step of the process: https://forms.gle/ZAVVn6c3T1TFTk5w6 3. Complete the CPT Canvas module quiz (this you will be able to see in your Canvas and is different from ANLY905)and complete the CPT Form (CPT Request Form (Public) (1).pdf) , and all related steps, thoroughly. 4. You are required to submit a 10 page paper. 5. Internships must begin between the first day of classes and the last day of add/drop, and must end between the last day of classes and the end of final exams.

title: 10  Student Mentorship Program
text:
10.1 Matching Mentors and Mentees
The Data Science & Analytics Student Mentorship Program was designed to provide support for incoming students, and to foster a sense of community among first-year and second-year students. Second-year student mentors act as a resource for new students and meet with their mentees throughout the academic year. Look for an email from me in early summer! https://analytics.georgetown.edu/mentorship/

title: 11  Student Committees
text:
11.1 Student Events & Social Committee
This committee is comprised of a Social Chair and 5-76 committee members. Students work closely with our Communications & Events Coordinator to foster a strong sense of community and support within our program by hosting social and professional events, developing shared community spaces, providing more opportunities to connect with each other, and sharing feedback from the student body. foster a strong sense of community, support DSAN program events, assist with brainstorming new possibilities for events, and provide feedback from the student body. When needed, committee members may assist with social media content creation.

title: 11  Student Committees
text:
11.2 Student Academic & Curriculum Committee
This committee is comprised of 2-3 first-year and 2-3 second-year student representatives. Representatives serve as liaisons between students and DSAN faculty & leadership. They are expected to be available to the DSAN student body to gather feedback about classes, and work with DSAN leadership to address concerns and implement suggestions.
https://analytics.georgetown.edu/dsan-student-committees/
You can apply to join these committees in early Fall!

title: 12  Electronic Resources (NetID, Email, Canvas)
text:
You already have a Georgetown University network identification, NetID. It is your initials followed by a few digits. Please refer to your admissions letter for your NetID, temporary password, and instructions for activating your NetID. Your NetID also defines your Georgetown email address. For example, if your NetID is abc278, also your Georgetown email address will be abc278@georgetown.edu. Always and continuously check your Georgetown email! Check it every day starting now and ending after you graduate. Your NetID will also grant you access to Georgetown systems – such as MyAccess and Canvas. While you are on campus, you will be able to access the wireless network using your NetID. CANVAS
Canvas is a course management system that your instructors will be using for your course grades and other course interaction. You can access Canvas using your NetID and password from a web browser or via the app for smartphones and tablets. Other electronic services for you to explore are at https://uis.georgetown.edu/new-to-georgetown/ and http://www.library.georgetown.edu. GO CARDS
The GOCard is the official identification card of Georgetown University. It can also be used to make purchases on and off campus, as well as allowing you access to campus buildings and the gym. You must submit your photo prior to arriving on campus. Please visit the GOCard website for instructions on securing your GOCard.

title: 13  Housing and Transportation
text:
13.1 Housing
The Graduate School of Arts & Sciences is pleased to offer graduate student housing at a brand new apartment residence located at 55 H Street NW. Learn more here: https://grad.georgetown.edu/grad_housing/grad-housing-faqs/ In addition, the Office of Neighborhood Life is an excellent resource for off-campus options, particularly this page. There is also a wealth of housing and student life information on the Graduate School of Arts & Science’s website. Most graduate students at Georgetown University live near the campus, either in VA or MD. Many students choose to live in VA just across the Key Bridge so that they can walk across the bridge to class. Others live in MD and take the Metro to the Dupont Circle Bus station. The bus comes right to the campus. See the section below on transportation for more detail. Here is a Google map for reference: Georgetown AreaGeorgetown University is in the middle of the map. Arlington, VA is south of the river. Many graduate students rent space in houses as a group. You can also look for places using web resources such as Georgetown Off-Campus Housing Service (https://ochlistings.georgetown.edu) or Apartment Finder (https://www.apartmentfinder.com/) We have several first-year and second-year students who represent our program as Student Ambassadors. If you’d like a student’s perspective/advice on housing options (or anything else!), please email our Ambassadors at gradanalytics@georgetown.edu.

title: 13  Housing and Transportation
text:
13.2 Transportation
You can get to campus by car, bus/shuttle or bike/on foot. Parking in Georgetown is limited by day and time and also does not extend for more than 2 hours. Maps of bus lines serving Georgetown are at https://www.wmata.com/schedules/maps/ There is no Metro (subway) stop in Georgetown, but the university provides a free shuttle service (GUTS) that has pick-up and drop-off from the DUPONT and ROSSLYN Metro stations. Information about GUTS is at http://otm.georgetown.edu/guts Washington is great for bicycling and walking. Maps of bicycle friendly routes are at http://www.waba.org/resources/maps-and-documents/. There is also a good bicycle sharing system http://www.capitalbikeshare.com and electric scooter sharing at https://www.li.me/.
The Gym, The Library, and Graduate Student Study Areas Yates Field House (the gym) Georgetown University Library Graduate Student Spaces

title: 14  TA, Internship, and Job Opportunities
text:
14.1 Being a Teaching Assistant (TA)
Being a TA is a great experience. We often have many TA opportunities and these will only increase over time. We encourage first-term students to focus 100% on coursework and limit working as much as possible. Because first-term students should focus on coursework, TA positions are prioritized for second-term and second-year students. However, first-term students are eligible to apply. You will receive an email during the summer with information about the Fall TA application process.
crumbs: 14  TA, Internship, and Job Opportunities

title: 14  TA, Internship, and Job Opportunities
text:
14.2 Working and Internships
I strongly encourage students to take up internships during their study period. This experience can be immensely valuable and help you with finding jobs in the future. However, it is important to note that our program is rigorous and demands significant commitment and effort. Therefore, it is crucial to manage your time efficiently and effectively. To this end, I recommend considering summer internships, as they can provide a valuable opportunity to gain practical experience while managing your time effectively.
Domestic students may work as they wish. International students may choose to take internships via the DSAN 5925/CPT option. We will discuss this in great detail during the August workshop. International students may start accepting internships by Summer of 2024. No internships are permitted for Fall 2023 or Spring 2024. **Please note that this is international and domestic law (not our rules) so we cannot waive or change this policy. We encourage all students to participate in summer internships. There are special rules for international students. We will hold a workshop in August and will send out a separate email for understanding and getting internships for all students.
crumbs: 14  TA, Internship, and Job Opportunities

title: Logistics and Student Life
text:
As incoming students, we recognize that you may have many important questions and concerns—we hope that the sections in this portion of the handbook can help address some of them! We are just as excited as you are and look forward to addressing all of your inquiries, for any of these questions or concerns that you don’t find within the handbook.
We will be hosting several orientation events to help answer your questions. Also, if you have any questions about selecting your classes, please email me at purna.gamage@georgetown.edu or our course coordinator Prof. James at jh2343@georgetown.edu. You can also reach out to your Bootcamp TA, or email our team of current students at gradanalytics@georgetown.edu.
We are always here to help and support you!
Best wishes,
Dr. Purna Gamage
Program Director purna.gamage@georgetown.edu
Heather Connor Director of Student Services heather.connor@georgetown.edu
